1.09pm BST

If two-thirds of Italian MPs can't agree on a new president at the next two votes, then the fourth ballot will take place at which a clear majority is enough for victory. That's why Franco Marini isn't out of the reckoning, despite failing to win at the first vote (see 1pm)

Although... history is against him:

Updated at 1.14pm BST

1.00pm BST

Italian MPs fail to elect president at first ballot

The Italian parliament has just failed to elect a new president at their first round of voting today.

Former senate chief Franco Marini didn't win the support of two-thirds of MPs - the threshold for victory. He had appeared to be the frontrunner, after the centre-left Democratic party and the rightwing People of Freedom party had both backed him.

A new vote will take place his afternoon.

Our southern Europe editor, John Hooper, believes that a Marini victory (which is still possible at a future vote) could actually benefit the radical Five Star Movement:

Updated at 1.20pm BST

12.24pm BST

A couple of photos from the German vote - showing Angela Merkel in cheerful spirits:

12.07pm BST

Cyprus parliament expected to vote on bailout

Our correspondent in Athens, Helena Smith, has confirmed that officials in the Cyprus parliament expected to hold their own vote on the bailout deal, at some stage soon.

This potentially adds an extra hurdle to the rescue, as the Cypriot parliament sensationally rejected the original plan last month.

That vote helped to force a rethink, including abandoning the idea of taxing all savers in favour of a haircut on those with over €100,000 in the country's two largest banks.

It's not clear when the vote will come, though:

Helena writes:

Government officials in Nicosia are ruling out the 56-seat House voting on the €10bn euro rescue programme today.

One official, who had been in contact with the parliament about the issue, said MPs would need to study and debate the package before the ballot took place.

"As it is nobody has been given an official version yet so how could the vote take place?," she said. "Right now we have no idea when it will take place but for sure it won't be today."

Meanwhile, the anti-austerity front grows with deepening opposition to a haircut that increasing numbers say resembles more of a scalping. Cadres in the main opposition communist AKEL party are telling me that "every avenue, every alternative to the memorandum and Troika has to be studied."

(more details here)

Updated at 12.50pm BST

11.27am BST

Here are some of the key quotes from the Bundestag debate:

Finance minister Wolfgang Schäuble:

Step by step we are winning back confidence. If you look at the markets, there is still nervousness and uncertainty. But it is considerably less than three years, two years or one year ago.

The aid for Cyprus secures the successes we've already achieved in the euro zone. We must prevent the problems in Cyprus from unleashing new problems in other euro zone countries.

Frank-Walter Steinmeier of the opposition SPD, on the original plan to tax all savers in Cyprus:

Mr. Schäuble, whether you asked for this or simply joined others in supporting it, it was a huge mistake. It stoked fear and insecurity in Europe.

Updated at 12.40pm BST

11.09am BST

German MPs have also approved extending the maturity on Irish bailout loans, by a similarly wide margin.

Updated at 11.10am BST

11.04am BST

German public still back Merkel over crisis

The size of the majority - with 487 German MPs in favour of the Cyprus plan and just 102 against - should please Angela Merkel.

Opinion polls have found widespread approval of the chancellor's handling of the crisis, particularly the Cypriot bailout.

A poll conducted in Germany at the start of April found that almost two-thirds of the population thought Merkel had "acted correctly and decisively in the euro crisis".

Only 33% thought that the German government thought too little about the wellbeing of people in crisis-hit countries as it works to rescue the euro.

More details here.

Updated at 12.40pm BST

10.55am BST

Early reaction to the German vote

10.43am BST

Germany approves Cyprus rescue deal

The Bundestag has approved the bailout of Cyprus.

A total of 487 German MPs backed the package, with just 102 against. There were also 13 abstentions.

Updated at 10.44am BST

10.30am BST

Voting is underway in the Bundestag now …

Updated at 12.39pm BST

10.26am BST

France's record low borrowing costs at today's debt auction comes a day after president François Hollande said it would take longer than planned to get the country's deficit below 3% of GDP.

Clearly bond traders aren't worried - and probably actually welcome the news that Paris is prioritising growth over deficit reduction

Gráinne McCarthy of the WSJ comments:

Updated at 12.39pm BST

10.13am BST

Nick Spiro on the Spanish bond auction

Here's some reaction to this morning's successful Spanish bond auction (details here), from Nick Spiro of Spiro Sovereign Strategy:

Despite the distinctly softer tone in global equity markets, peripheral eurozone debt markets remain remarkably resilient.

As the "hunt for yield" continues unabated, Spanish and Italian bonds have been in something of a sweet spot for several months, benefiting from the higher carry, the perceived credibility of the ECB's backstop and, most recently, the sentiment-boosting policy actions of the Bank of Japan. Most investors are choosing to downplay idiosyncratic risks in Spain, of which there are too many to list, and treat the market as a high-return, as opposed to a high-risk, one. Markets have become more sensitive to the deterioration in the global growth outlook of late which suggests that economic fundamentals are starting to come into focus. 10.09am BST

Back in the Bundestag - Carsten Schneider of the opposition SPD party has apparently argued that shareholders in European banks should provide some funding towards a fund to cover failed banks.

Open Europe's Pawel Swidlicki got the quotes:

The FT's James Mackintosh isn't impressed.

Updated at 12.37pm BST

10.00am BST

France, meanwhile, just auctioned five- year bonds at a record low yield of just 0.73%.

Spanish bond aution results

Updated at 12.36pm BST

9.39am BST

8.45am BST

Schäuble's final message to Germany is that the country would be worse off if it quit the euro and returned to the Deutschemark (a policy favoured by its newest political party, Alternative für Deutschland).

Key event

The current youth unemployment levels in the euro area are "catastrophic", adds Schäuble.

A poll conducted in Germany at the start of April found that almost two-thirds of the population thought Merkel had "acted correctly and decisively in the euro crisis". Only 33% thought that the German government thought too little about the wellbeing of people in crisis-hit countries as it works to rescue the euro. More details here. The Bundestag has approved the bailout of Cyprus. A total of 487 German MPs backed the package, with just 102 against. There were also 13 abstentions. Voting is underway in the Bundestag now … France's record low borrowing costs at today's debt auction comes a day after president François Hollande said it would take longer than planned to get the country's deficit below 3% of GDP. Clearly bond traders aren't worried - and probably actually welcome the news that Paris is prioritising growth over deficit reduction Gráinne McCarthy of the WSJ comments: Here's some reaction to this morning's successful Spanish bond auction (details here), from Nick Spiro of Spiro Sovereign Strategy: Despite the distinctly softer tone in global equity markets, peripheral eurozone debt markets remain remarkably resilient. As the "hunt for yield" continues unabated, Spanish and Italian bonds have been in something of a sweet spot for several months, benefiting from the higher carry, the perceived credibility of the ECB's backstop and, most recently, the sentiment-boosting policy actions of the Bank of Japan. Most investors are choosing to downplay idiosyncratic risks in Spain, of which there are too many to list, and treat the market as a high-return, as opposed to a high-risk, one. Today's well received auction, with a further drop in yields and robust demand, underscores the extent to which peripheral eurozone debt markets are almost immune from growing concerns about economic growth. Complacency is wearing thin, though, Spiro adds: Markets have become more sensitive to the deterioration in the global growth outlook of late which suggests that economic fundamentals are starting to come into focus. This recent shift in sentiment is likely to seep into Spanish and Italian bond markets. Yet, as we have been arguing for some time, the bar for a sharp and sustained sell-off in Spanish and Italian debt has risen significantly since last July. Country-specific risk remains a weak determinant of Spanish and Italian spreads. Back in the Bundestag - Carsten Schneider of the opposition SPD party has apparently argued that shareholders in European banks should provide some funding towards a fund to cover failed banks. Open Europe's Pawel Swidlicki got the quotes: The FT's James Mackintosh isn't impressed. But the plan does seem in line with the SPD's policy of removing the "implicit guarantee" that taxpayers will rescue banks (see more details here). France, meanwhile, just auctioned five- year bonds at a record low yield of just 0.73%. Reassuring for Paris, but also a sign that money is pouring into sovereign debt as central banks around the world ease monetary policy. Yesterday, the IMF warned of the risk that quantitative easing and ultra-low interest rates are fueling the next asset bubble. Some good news for Spain - it just sold around €4.7bn of government debt at lower interest rates. The auction included €1.29bn of 10-year bonds (the key measure of sovereign risk) at an average yield of just 4.612%, down from 4.898% last time. That looks like Spain's lowest borrowing cost for 10 years since September 2010. Britain's retail sales took a nasty dip in March, falling by 0.7% month on month, according to data just released by the Office for National Statistics. The awful UK weather is being blamed, along with the wider economic problems (yesterday's unemployment data showed that the gap between real wages and rising prices had widened). New jobless data from the Netherlands shows that the country's labour market deteriorated sharply last month. The jobless rate in the Netherlands rose to 8.1% in March, on a seasonally adjusted basis, from 7.7% in February. Twelve months ago it was 5.9%. Gregor Gysi of the leftwing Linke MP was very critical of the Cyprus rescue and its impact on ordinary people such as teachers and pensioners, who will pay for a crisis they didn't cause. Gysi also tells the Bundestag that Cyprus's own MPs have yet to give their approval for the plan. We should wait and see what they decide, he suggests. This follows reports that the Cypriot parliament will vote on the bailout, which is a surprise. We're looking into it today, and CNBC has more details here. Gysi also blasts those responsible for the original bailout plan (which includes Wolfgang Schäuble) for "confusing" savers with the plan to tax all deposits. As well as the Cyprus package, German MPs are also considering the decision to extend some of Portugal and Ireland's bailout loans for another seven years. Frank-Walter Steinmeier of the SPD opposition speaks next, and seems to argue that while his party will back the Cyprus package, that does not mean it consents to the way Germany is handing the crisis. He also criticises Schäuble for not mentioning the International Monetary Fund's latest forecasts (it now expects a 0.3% contraction in the eurozone this year). Schäuble's final message to Germany is that the country would be worse off if it quit the euro and returned to the Deutschemark (a policy favoured by its newest political party, Alternative für Deutschland). The current youth unemployment levels in the euro area are "catastrophic", adds Schäuble. Update: here's the full quote via Reuters: We must fight in particular the high levels of youth unemployment in a number of European countries It is a catastrophe if 30-40 percent of young people have no job in the long term. Few would argue that a jobless rate of 23.5% for young people (and 12% across the board) is indeed awful. The highest rates are in Greece and Spain (both enforcing the kinds of austerity programmes favoured by Berlin...) Schäuble insists that there is "no other sustainable course" to repair the eurozone, other than by the current approach of fiscal consolidation and structural reforms. The plan is "beginning to bear fruit", he adds. European Parliament Advisor Roderick Kefferputz isn't convinced: There's no chance of Cyprus being given more than €10bn in loans from the EU and the IMF, says Schäuble. That's follows leaked documents earlier this month which suggested the total cost of the programme is now €23bn, not €17bn (although the situation is still unclear). There is a serious risk of contagion sweeping through Europe if Cyprus is not rescued, Schäuble says, as he urges the Bundestag to back the package (as we expect them to do). Spain and Italy could both have been hit, he adds. MPs are giving Schäuble a good reception - he's already won a couple of rounds of applause. Wolfgang Schäuble opened the debate by telling the Bundestag that the situation in the eurozone had improved during 2013. The euro crisis is clearly causing less uncertainty in the financial markets than a few months ago, he argued. And Schäuble insisted that Europe was right to bail out Cyprus, due the "dramatic" situation the island found itself. Without help, the Cypriot government would have defaulted on its loans, he warns, spreading more alarm through the eurozone and beyond. There's a live stream from the Bundestag here. Incidentally, before the Cyprus bailout was agreed there was a lot of concern in Germany that dubious Russian businesspeople might benefit from a rescue deal. Not any more, as euobserver points out: the issue of alleged money laundering by Cypriot banks - the number one topic in Germany ahead of the eurozone deal - seems to have been kicked into the long grass. Italian MPs will also be busy today, as they begin the process of electing a new president. Their choice could have serious consequences for the rest of the eurozone, as whoever succeeds Giorgio Napolitano must try to form a stable government. As my colleague Lizzy Davies wrote last night: It will be up to Napolitano's successor to see whether bickering politicians can be cajoled into forming a government or whether a return to the polls is the only way forward.... More here: Italian politicians go into conclave for crucial presidential election Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the eurozone crisis and other events across the global economy. Cyprus is top of the agenda today, as MPs gather at the Reichstag building in Berlin to debate its bailout package. Finance minister Wolfgang Schäuble will open the debate at 8am BST (9am local time), with a vote taking place around 10am BST. The debate is likely to include heavy criticism of the way the plan was put together. MPs could also raise concerns that the growth projections in the programme are too optimistic. The Bundestag must give its approval before €10bn of EU/IMF loans can be extended to the Cypriot government, part of the package that was hammered out last month. The package is likely to be approved, as some opposition MPs have already indicated they will vote alongside Angela Merkel's government. Green MP Tobias Lindner said yesterday: ...everything indicates there will be a large majority on Thursday. Lindner added that there is likely to be lengthy questioning of how Cyprus's rising debts will be kept at "sustainable", given the damage caused to the country's economy in recent weeks. We'll be tracking events in the Bundestag this morning, and across Europe and beyond through the day …
